title: I’ve set up a multi-agent architecture using Semantic Kernel where:
body:
I’ve set up a multi-agent architecture using Semantic Kernel where:

1. A Main Router Agent is responsible for routing queries.
2. Several specialized agents (screening, fundflow, counter, pivot, irregularities, file_chat, general) are wrapped with their own logic (token tracking, memory, validation).
3. All agents share a single Kernel, and the router is initialized with these wrappers as plugins.

The issue I’m observing is that when a user sends a query, the router agent sometimes directly calls kernel_function tools exposed by the wrappers, instead of delegating through the full specialized agent logic. This bypasses my wrappers’ additional responsibilities (like per-agent token cost tracking and memory handling).

My questions for the community:

1. Is this expected behavior when adding wrapper plugins to a ChatCompletionAgent?
2. Or is the recommended approach to give each specialized agent its own Kernel and keep them isolated?

I’d appreciate guidance on the best practice for building multi-agent flows in Semantic Kernel, especially for ensuring all requests go through the full wrapper logic (token tracking, mem0 memory, etc.), rather than being shortcut by direct tool calls.

My architecture is
User Question -> get the past history -> pass it to orch agent (invoke/get_response) -> wrote a wrapper class for specialized agent -> orch agent should invoke the wrapper class (tool) to call that specialized agent -> the specialized agent has a list of kernel_function (tools) in it -> It will call the tool accordingly based on the question

But what is happening is
User Question -> get the past history -> pass it to orch agent (invoke/get_response) -> directly calling the kerenl function tool

Instead of calling the specialized agent, this is what happening

orchestrator_agent.py
```import os
from semantic_kernel.agents import ChatCompletionAgent
from dotenv import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()

def create_main_router_agent(general_wrapper, screening_wrapper, fundflow_wrapper, counter_wrapper, irregularities_wrapper, pivot_wrapper, file_chat_wrapper,kernel):
    """Create Level 1 Main Router Agent that routes between different analysis agents."""
    main_router_instructions = """You are an intelligent financial transaction"""
    
    api_key = os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY")
    
    if not api_key:
        raise ValueError("Missing OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable")
    
    print("🔄 Creating Main Router Agent...")
    main_router_agent = ChatCompletionAgent(
        id="MainRouterAgent",
        name="MainRouterAgent", 
        instructions=main_router_instructions,
        description="Main router that routes between different financial analysis agents.",
        plugins=[general_wrapper, screening_wrapper, counter_wrapper, fundflow_wrapper, pivot_wrapper, irregularities_wrapper, file_chat_wrapper],
        kernel=kernel
    )
    
    return main_router_agent
```

general_wrapper.py
```# general_agent.py
from typing import Annotated
from semantic_kernel.agents import ChatCompletionAgent
from semantic_kernel.functions import kernel_function
from plugins.general_plugin import GeneralPlugin
from dotenv import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()

async def create_general_agent(kernel):
    """Create the general agent for handling general queries about features and capabilities."""
    
    try:
        print(" Creating General Agent with OpenAI...")
        
        general_instructions = """
You are a Financial Intelligence Analyst specializing in advanced analytics, pattern recognition, and complex computational analysis for financial investigation and compliance.
"""
     general_agent = ChatCompletionAgent(
            kernel=kernel,
            name="general-agent",
            instructions=general_instructions,
            plugins=[GeneralPlugin()]
        )
        
        return {
            'general_agent': general_agent,
            'kernel': kernel,
        }
        
    except Exception as e:
        print(f" Error creating general agent: {e}")
        return None
class GeneralWrapper:
    """Wrapper plugin that calls the General Agent."""
    
    def __init__(self, general_agent):
        self.general_agent = general_agent
    
    @kernel_function(description="Handle feature explanations, suspicion analysis, and transaction pattern queries and all other general queries.",
                                          name="handle_general_request")
    async def handle_general_request(
        self, 
        query: Annotated[str, "The general query about system features or capabilities"]
    ) -> Annotated[str, "General information and guidance"]:
        """Handle general support requests."""
        try:
            print(" Processing general support request...")
            
            response = await self.general_agent.get_response(
                messages=query
            )
            
            return f"General Support: {response.content}"
                
        except Exception as e:
            print(f" General support handling error: {str(e)}")
            return "I apologize for the error. Please try again or contact support."
```

shared_kernel.py
```
# shared_kernel.py
import os
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from semantic_kernel import Kernel
from semantic_kernel.connectors.ai.open_ai import OpenAIChatCompletion

load_dotenv()

def create_shared_kernel():
    """Create simple shared kernel with OpenAI service"""
    api_key = os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY")
    model_id = os.getenv("OPENAI_CHAT_MODEL_ID", "gpt-4o-mini")
    if not api_key:
        raise ValueError("Missing OPENAI_API_KEY")

    print("🔧 Creating simple shared kernel with OpenAI service...")

    kernel = Kernel()
    kernel.add_service(OpenAIChatCompletion(ai_model_id=model_id, api_key=api_key))

    print("✅ Simple shared kernel created")
    return kernel```
    
    main.py
    ```

async def initialize_agents():
    """Initialize all agents once at startup."""
    
    kernel = create_shared_kernel()
    general_data = await create_general_agent(kernel)
    screening_data = await create_screen_agent(kernel)
    Fundflow_data = await create_fundflow_agent(kernel)
    counter_data = await create_counter_agent(kernel)
    irregularities_data = await create_irregualrties_agent(kernel)
    pivot_data = await create_pivot_agent(kernel)
    file_chat_data = await create_file_chat_agent(kernel)
    
    if not general_data or not screening_data or not Fundflow_data or not counter_data or not irregularities_data or not pivot_data or not file_chat_data:
        raise Exception("Failed to initialize specialized agents")
    
    general_wrapper = GeneralWrapper(
        general_data['general_agent'])
    
    screening_wrapper = ScreeningWrapper(
        screening_data['screening_agent'])
    
    fundflow_wrapper = FundflowWrapper(
        Fundflow_data['fundflow_agent'])
    
    counter_wrapper = CounterWrapper(
        counter_data['counter_agent'])
    
    irregularities_wrapper = IrregulartiesWrapper(
        irregularities_data['irregularities_agent'])
    
    pivot_wrapper = PivotWrapper(
        pivot_data['pivot_agent'])
    
    file_chat_wrapper = FileChatWrapper(
        file_chat_data['file_chat_agent'])
    
    router_agent = create_main_router_agent(general_wrapper, screening_wrapper, fundflow_wrapper, counter_wrapper, irregularities_wrapper, pivot_wrapper, file_chat_wrapper,kernel)
    
    GLOBAL_AGENTS.update({
        'router': router_agent,
    })
    
    print("✅ All agents initialized successfully")

```

we are invoking the main agent like this

``` 
response = await GLOBAL_AGENTS['router'].get_response(
                messages=final_query,
                thread=thread
            )
```

_Originally posted by @Mamlesh18 in https://github.com/microsoft/semantic-kernel/discussions/13081_

VSCode version:

```

In the diff editor, I sometimes want to reveal a bit of the unchanged code for more context around the changes. It’s convenient that I can simply click and drag to do this. However, when I drag the cursor beyond the viewport, the editor doesn’t scroll along, forcing me to scroll back manually and try again. title: Regex crashes application
body:
Type: Performance Issue I was running a regex search to try and find specific entries in a ~30k line lua definition file. First I wanted to find all files with this entry in the project, but that crashed the application, so I thought just try it in a file I know has the entry. That also crashed the application. So I tried creating a new file with just that entry, 6 lines, and it still crashed the application. I can only conclude that it is the regex handling that crashes the application, rather than the fetching of the results. The error in the log is "UnresponsiveSampleError", and the regex I was attempting to use is: metal_shelves = \{(\n|[^}])*?procList(\n|[^}])*?name="ChefOutfit"(\n|[^}])*?\} It is meant to find all metal_shelves tables that has a subtable procList that has an entry with the name ChefOutfit. Example entry: metal_shelves = { procedural = true, procList = { {name="ChefTools", min=1, max=4}, } }, If I remove one \n entry (for example "metal_shelves = \{(\n|[^}])*?" it will work, but won't find relevant results. It is only when I search for all relevant results that the application crashes. My suspicion therefore is that VS Code has issues handling too many newlines in regex searches, across the board. title: Option to prevent automatic editor pane resizing

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: workbench-editors
labels.description: Managing of editor widgets in workbench window

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

**Feature request**:

When an editor group has been manually shrunk by dragging its divider, focusing that group using "View: Focus Next Editor Group" (keyboard shortcut) restores/un-minimizes it, to an even larger size than it started. I cannot find a setting to prevent this behavior.

Use case: I arrange editor groups to specific sizes for my workflow. Automatic resizing when cycling focus requires me to stop using the keyboard and manually resize dividers with the mouse, and disrupts flow and context.

Typically I make them smaller to get a temporarily unneeded group of open tabs out of the way, meaning I don't want to see it again until I manually drag it back.

Request: Please add an option to disable automatic resizing of editor group sizes when changing focus, or provide a setting to preserve manual sizes exactly. A preference like "workbench.editor.preserveGroupSizesOnFocus": true would address this.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open at least two editor groups.
2. Drag the divider to make one group very small.
3. Focus the small group using "View: Focus Next Editor Group" (keyboard shortcut).

Expected/desired: Focus moves without changing the manually set group sizes.
Observed: The small group is expanded/restored automatically.

**Video**: Here is a video from 2018 demonstrating the same automatic resizing (that commenter likes it!): https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/53702#issuecomment-403017412

Thanks for considering this enhancement.

title: AI-IDE Integration Bug Report
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No

- VS Code Version: Latest (as of Sept 2025)
- OS Version: Windows

### Bug Description
Critical issue with state management in VS Code's AI integration (GitHub Copilot) affecting file modifications and version control during AI-assisted coding sessions.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open VS Code with GitHub Copilot enabled
2. Create or open an existing code file (e.g., JavaScript)
3. Request AI to make multiple iterative changes to the same file
4. Observe file state between changes
5. Attempt to make additional changes to the same file

### Expected Behavior
- AI should see and modify the current state of the file
- Changes should be atomic and consistent
- File content should maintain integrity between modifications

### Actual Behavior
1. State Management Issues:
   - AI simultaneously sees multiple versions of the same file
   - File content becomes corrupted with merged states
   - Example: `const puppeteer = r` merging with existing try block

2. Version Control Conflicts:
   - System tracks multiple states simultaneously
   - Changes apply to incorrect base versions
   - No clear "current" state for AI reference

### Code Corruption Example
```javascript
const puppeteer = r    try {  // Corrupted state example
        await page.goto('https://www.seek.com.au/job/86893060', {
```

### Impact
- Corrupted file contents
- Interrupted development flow
- Need for manual intervention
- Reduced trust in AI-assisted changes

### Workarounds Discovered
1. Single Change Protocol:
   - Make one atomic change per interaction
   - Delete and rewrite entire files instead of partial changes
   - Implement manual verification steps

2. Session Management:
   - Avoid terminating during context summarization
   - Maintain separate documentation for context
   - Accept temporary precision loss for continuity

### Additional Notes
- Issue appears related to git-like version control integration
- Tool responses indicate awareness of corruption (failing safely)
- Different AI models may interpret/modify documentation differently
- Context summarization exhibits lag during transitions

### Environment Details
- VS Code with GitHub Copilot
- Multiple file editing scenarios
- Reproducible across different file types
- Observed consistently in development workflow

title: Feature Request: Add Environment Variable for Copilot Terminal Sessions
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
## Summary
Add a unique environment variable to distinguish when AI assistants (like GitHub Copilot) are executing terminal commands, allowing users to conditionally disable shell features that interfere with AI tool output.

## Problem Statement
Currently, when AI assistants execute terminal commands through VS Code, they inherit the same environment variables as regular user terminal sessions. This causes issues when users have shell configurations that:

- Auto-start tmux/screen sessions (which mangle AI tool output)
- Display interactive prompts or menus
- Run background processes or watch commands
- Use complex prompt configurations that interfere with command output parsing

Users need a way to detect AI-initiated terminal sessions to conditionally disable these features.

## Proposed Solution
Add a new environment variable when AI assistants execute terminal commands:

```bash
VSCODE_COPILOT_TERMINAL=1
# or alternatively
COPILOT_TERMINAL=1
# or
VSCODE_ASSISTANT_SESSION=1
```

## Use Cases

### 1. Conditional tmux/screen startup
```bash
# In .zshrc/.bashrc
if [[ -z "$VSCODE_COPILOT_TERMINAL" && -z "$TMUX" ]]; then
    tmux attach-session -t default || tmux new-session -s default
fi
```

### 2. Simplified prompt for AI sessions
```bash
# Provide clean output for AI parsing
if [[ -n "$VSCODE_COPILOT_TERMINAL" ]]; then
    PS1="$ "
else
    # Complex prompt with git info, colors, etc.
    PS1="..."
fi
```

### 3. Disable interactive features
```bash
if [[ -z "$VSCODE_COPILOT_TERMINAL" ]]; then
    # Only show welcome messages for human users
    echo "Welcome back, $(whoami)!"
    # Load interactive aliases and functions
fi
```

## Current Workaround
Users currently have to detect AI sessions indirectly by checking for existing VS Code variables like `VSCODE_INJECTION`, but this affects all VS Code terminals, not just AI-initiated ones.

## Benefits
- **Better AI Tool Reliability**: Cleaner command output improves AI parsing accuracy
- **User Experience**: Eliminates conflicts between user shell configurations and AI tools
- **Flexibility**: Allows users to customize their environment for both human and AI interactions
- **Backward Compatible**: No impact on existing functionality

## Implementation Notes
- Should be set only when AI assistants execute terminal commands
- Should not be set for regular user-initiated VS Code terminal sessions
- Could potentially be scoped per AI assistant type if multiple assistants are supported

## Environment Details
- **VS Code Version**: [Current]
- **OS**: macOS, Windows, Linux
- **Shell**: bash, zsh, fish, etc.

---

**Additional Context**: This issue arose from practical experience where tmux auto-start configurations were interfering with AI assistant terminal output, making it difficult for AI tools to parse command results effectively and stating that the output was "mangled".

- **VS Code Version:** 1.101.0
- **OS Version:** Windows 10.0.26100
- **Feature:** Chat (ask mode)
- **Selected model:** GPT-4.1
- **Logs:** No logs available—error occurs immediately on prompt submission

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Launch VS Code from Anaconda Prompt using `code`
2. Create a new workspace with a single `.py` file
3. Type `"hi"` or any minimal prompt into Copilot Chat
4. Observe error: `413 Request Entity Too Large`

**Expected Behavior:**

Copilot Chat should respond with a completion or suggestion for minimal prompts.

**Actual Behavior:**

Copilot Chat fails with a 413 error immediately, regardless of prompt size or workspace context.

**Additional Context:**

This issue blocks all use of Copilot Chat. I've confirmed similar reports in [Issue #12847](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-release/issues/12847) and [Issue #8728](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-release/issues/8728), but the problem persists even after those threads were closed.  
I've tried:
- Reinstalling extension (release and prerelease)
- Clearing VS Code cache
- Disabling context
- Signing out/in from GitHub
- Rebooting system and launching from clean environment

title: Allow agents to use a global absolute project directory path
body:
Description:
It would be very helpful if GitHub Copilot could allow agents to define a global absolute project directory path. This would prevent potential errors when running command-line operations due to incorrect directory switching.

Example scenario:
In my project, there are both client and server directories, each requiring npm commands to be executed within its respective directory. Currently, if the agent doesn’t switch to the correct directory, commands may fail.

Suggested approach:
The agent could always execute commands using a format like:

`cd {projectpath}/client && npm run build`

This ensures consistency and reduces unexpected errors during command execution.

Benefits:

1. More reliable command execution
2. Reduced errors caused by incorrect directory context
3. Easier project automation with multi-directory setups

Optional:
It would be great if this feature could be configured globally for the entire project, so agents always know the correct base path.

title: Hide "Generate instructions" hint when workspace already has instruction files
body:
The "Generate instructions" hint was always showing on the chat welcome page, even when the workspace already contained instruction files like `.github/copilot-instructions.md` or `agents.md`. This created a poor user experience where users were prompted to generate instructions they had already created.

## Changes

**Added `hasAnyInstructionFiles()` method to `ComputeAutomaticInstructions`:**
- Checks for existing `.github/copilot-instructions.md` files (when `github.copilot.chat.codeGeneration.useInstructionFiles` is enabled)  
- Checks for existing `agents.md` files (when `chat.useAgentsMdFile` is enabled)
- Uses the same file detection logic as the existing instruction collection system
- Respects the same configuration settings

**Modified welcome message logic in `ChatWidget`:**
- Added `_getGenerateInstructionsMessage()` method that asynchronously checks for instruction files
- Shows empty message initially to avoid flickering, then updates when file check completes
- Only displays the "Generate instructions" hint when no instruction files are found
- Caches the result to avoid repeated file system checks

## Behavior

| Scenario | Before | After |
|----------|--------|-------|
| Workspace with `.github/copilot-instructions.md` | Shows hint | No hint |
| Workspace with `agents.md` | Shows hint | No hint |
| Workspace with both files | Shows hint | No hint |
| Workspace without instruction files | Shows hint | Shows hint |
| Instruction file settings disabled | Shows hint | Shows hint |

This ensures users only see the "Generate instructions" hint when it's actually relevant to their workspace setup.

Fixes #265440.

title: Be smarter about errors from edits

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
@roblourens 
> [conversation.md](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/20914452/conversation.md)
> 
> For this thing `The edit resulted in the following lint errors:` we try to diff errors before and after each edit. But, I've seen that it may introduce errors in one edit, then do another that doesn't fix those errors, and then never fix the errors, like in the attached run.
> 
> I don't know exactly how it would work but maybe we could track errors that were previously introduced by an edit in the session, and still include those until they are fixed. Or I would like it to use get_errors to check its work more but it doesn't do that.
> 
> Or even simpler, maybe we just include some preexisting errors "These errors were in the file before the current edit, and still exist".

title: Chat rollback bug

labels.name: chat-ext-issue
labels.description: Triaging assistance tag. Automatically applied if an issue comes from the chat oss repo.

body:
Not only does the same issue persist from WEEKS ago, (messages getting stuck indefinitely on "Working"), but now, to top it all off, upon restarting VS Code, a large number of chat messages are being deleted, rolling back to a certain point.

Fortunately, this rollback isn't affecting files, only the chat messages. But it's absolutely IMPOSSIBLE to work when I have to explain everything from scratch in every message what's happening and what needs to be done; and then, as soon as it starts working again for a bit, everything hangs once more, and on top of that, the chat rolls back again.

This is happening with VS Code Insiders updated to the latest version, including both releases from today, September 5th.

title: Keyboard shortcut for navigating previous/next chat messages in Chat sidebar
body:
Introduce configurable keyboard shortcuts that allow users to:

- Move focus to the previous user chat message in the Chat sidebar
- Move focus to the next user chat message in the Copilot Chat sidebar
- Optionally, cycle only through user messages (excluding assistant responses)

These shortcuts should be customizable in the Keyboard Shortcuts settings and work regardless of the current input focus inside the chat panel sidebar.

Today, the user can use <kbd>Shift</kbd>+ Arrow to move through pages. A good modifier could be `Ctrl` + `Shift` + Arrow.

title: FUCK YOU>U>UY
AI Agent Reports Successful File Edits But No Changes Are Written to Disk

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 49.456.167
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: Linuxmint - Linux Mint 21 - Release: 21 -  vanessa
- Feature Agent  (file modification through chat)
- Selected GPT 4.1 and Claude 4 Sonnet
- Logs: - Multiple attempts to modify files show no Copilot-specific error messages
- Only warnings present: "GitHub.vscode-pull-request-github extension API is not available" (unrelated to file writing issue)
- Test file creation outside main workspace generated expected warnings about external files
- No error logs generated when agent reports successful edits to main workspace files
- Absence of relevant logs suggests agent believes operations are successful despite no actual file changes

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code with local workspace `/home/buttu/libera-sphere` (Next.js project)
2. Open existing file `src/app/page.tsx` in the editor
3. Request AI agent via chat to modify the file (e.g., "add a comment to page.tsx")
4. Observe agent response: "The following files were successfully edited: /home/buttu/libera-sphere/src/app/page.tsx"
5. Check actual file content - no changes are visible
6. Verify file permissions are correct: `ls -l src/app/page.tsx` shows `rw-rw-r--`
7. Confirm manual editing works: manually add/remove text and save successfully
8. Repeat steps 3-5 multiple times with different modification requests
9. Test agent writing to files outside this workspace - works correctly
10. Test agent creating new files in this workspace - reports success but files remain empty

Expected Result: File modifications should be written to disk when agent reports success

Actual Result: Agent consistently reports successful edits but no changes appear in files

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

From the native windows code cli executable, I can initiate a chat using the `code chat "hello world" subcommand. I can do the same in macos. But, when using the code cli bridge from a wsl session, the subcommand is just not available. I would like to have the same experience of all systems so that I can script some prompt without having to create a vscode extension with a chat participant. Currently, this would only be possible for a subset of users.

title: Coding agent getting started experience
body: As we're discussing the Chat Sessions view rollout, @rebornix had an idea to test `chat.agentSessionsViewLocation` in a fresh transient VS Code Insiders. **Setup:** - Launch fresh VS Code Insiders - Set `"chat.agentSessionsViewLocation": "view"` Using latest VS Code Insiders: ``` Version: 1.104.0-insider (user setup) Commit: 06acd067cb9621b055d9701324477cf75fa0e242 Date: 2025-09-05T09:02:10.455Z Electron: 37.3.1 ElectronBuildId: 12259562 Chromium: 138.0.7204.235 Node.js: 22.18.0 V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT arm64 10.0.26100 ``` **Here's my experience. I used ❔ to indicate a minor polish opportunity and❓ to indicate something that may be a larger polish opportunity or bug.** **Local chats** - I see the Chat Sessions view icon appear in the Activity Bar (after setting `"chat.agentSessionsViewLocation": "view"`). When I click it, things look good: - - Create a new local chat editor - - - Send a message - Copilot is installed pretty seamlessly, and I'm guided to sign in - - ❔ After signing in, the Copilot extension getting started takes over focus. Would we consider this distracting? Either way, not a blocker, just potentially a bit disruptive - - I navigate back to local chat editor, looks good - - **Coding agent sessions** - Learn More button works well (brings me to our docs) - Select `Install Chat Extensions`; works well, I now have `GitHub Copilot Coding Agent` section in the Chat Sessions view, and I see the GHPR extension in the Activity Bar - - - ❓ I notice I can `+` to create new coding agent sessions, even though I don't have a repo open, and then I get a failure that doesn't guide me to why it failed. Can we provide better guidance here (i.e. for users to open a folder)? - - - - I open a folder in VS Code - I'm guided to trust the workspace and sign in further to chat - - ❓ After signing in, I still don't see any sessions in the `GitHub Copilot Coding Agent` section of the Chat Sessions view, even though I know this repo has coding agent sessions: - - I got a GHPR extension update at this time, so I restarted my extension host - Now I see my sessions - - I'm able to initiate a new coding agent session from the `+` successfully - - I can also delegate via the cloud button in the chat panel successfully - - The status bar entry and GHPR both properly show 2 sessions in progress - -

It lasts about 10 minutes after opening the workspace: ``` 2025-09-05 11:28:48.363 [info] > git rev-parse --show-toplevel [705ms] 2025-09-05 11:28:48.363 [info] fatal: not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git 2025-09-05 11:28:48.364 [info] > git rev-parse --show-toplevel [423ms] 2025-09-05 11:28:48.365 [info] fatal: not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git 2025-09-05 11:28:48.366 [info] > git rev-parse --show-toplevel [923ms] 2025-09-05 11:28:48.366 [info] fatal: not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git 2025-09-05 11:28:48.419 [info] > git rev-parse --show-toplevel [674ms] 2025-09-05 11:28:48.419 [info] fatal: not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git 2025-09-05 11:28:48.815 [info] > git rev-parse --show-toplevel [830ms] 2025-09-05 11:28:48.815 [info] fatal: not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git 2025-09-05 11:28:48.818 [info] > git rev-parse --show-toplevel [542ms] 2025-09-05 11:28:48.818 [info] fatal: not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git 2025-09-05 11:28:48.818 [info] > git rev-parse --show-toplevel [581ms] 2025-09-05 11:28:48.819 [info] fatal: not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git ``` This does NOT happen when copilot is disabled, so it isn't a problem with the builtin git repository scanning I have several very large folders open: one is my main project, 2 are related projects I sometimes like to see the code for, and 2 are the entire python library for multiple venvs, including the active one and about 12 more I set `git.autoRepositoryDetection` to false, assuming this output was related to that, but it isn't; it's related to copilot I also set the log level on the git window to "trace", but copilot is still only showing those [info] logs pasted above. title: Copilots needs to be integrated into the VS Code debugger - Move the Needle!
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Integrate co-pilot with the VS Code debugger

This would be a game changer!

I use VS Code every day and every day we go through this cycle of “let me add some logging to understand what is happening” and then 30 minutes later we might get an answer.  That is like 1985 thinking before debuggers were a thing.  If I fire up the debugger and cut and paste screen shots we get an answer in 10 minutes but that is a laborious and needless process.

If instead the agent, which already can see the code, would be able to work with the debugger or at least see it we would be done in 5 seconds or less.  All of these debuggers like in VS Code are built on top of a command line debugger.  Cut and paste or logging is a very sad substitute.

In the real world of existing code debugger integration is absolutely a necessity and would turn VS Code into a really essential part of everyday coding.  AI is only as smart as the information it has and if only has a static view of the code that’s about half of what it really needs.

Give the dang AI some glasses for goodness sake.

title: Chat: Fix vertical grid alignment of tool calls by reducing paragraph margin
body:
The chat interface had inconsistent vertical spacing that prevented tool calls from aligning properly in a vertical grid. Normal text paragraphs used 16px bottom margin while tool invocation paragraphs used only 6px, creating visual misalignment.

**Before (16px):**
- Tool calls appeared misaligned with regular text
- Inconsistent vertical rhythm disrupted readability

**After (6px):**
- Clean vertical grid alignment between all chat elements
- Consistent spacing creates better visual hierarchy

This change updates the CSS rule for `.interactive-item-container .value > .rendered-markdown p` to use `margin: 0 0 6px 0` instead of `margin: 0 0 16px 0`, matching the existing spacing used by tool invocation parts.

The fix ensures tool calls are "nicely aligned as a vertical grid" as requested, improving the overall chat interface layout without affecting functionality.

Fixes #265369.

title: Fix chat elicitation prompt button vertical growth in flex containers
body:
Chat elicitation prompt buttons were growing vertically when placed in flex containers with available horizontal space, causing inconsistent UI appearance. This was particularly noticeable in terminal confirmation dialogs where buttons would stretch to fill the container height instead of maintaining their intended size.

## Problem
The chat confirmation widget buttons lacked height constraints, allowing flex containers with `align-items: stretch` or similar properties to expand buttons vertically beyond their intended dimensions.

**Before - Buttons growing vertically:**
![Before - Button growing vertically](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/15925c8e-6ae3-4a81-8431-de65de62811b)

## Solution
Added `height: 24px` specifically to chat elicitation prompt buttons in the chat confirmation widget CSS:
- `.chat-confirmation-widget .chat-buttons .monaco-button`
- `.chat-confirmation-widget2 .chat-confirmation-widget-buttons .chat-buttons .monaco-button`

This targeted approach ensures only the problematic chat elicitation prompt buttons have the height constraint, while preserving the natural behavior of other buttons throughout VS Code. The height is set to 24px to match other chat dialog buttons for consistency.

**After - Fixed button height:**
![Test showing the fix working correctly](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/707a38c7-b9ed-4a88-8faf-f4d6b5b7a85b)

The fix ensures chat elicitation prompt buttons maintain their intended height of 24px regardless of container flex properties, while preserving proper horizontal centering and content alignment for all other buttons in the application.

Fixes #265382.

title: Border around vscode
body: Type: Feature Request Is it possible to add an option to put a small greyish border around vscode? When using dark mode, it's hard to tell where the edges of the window. I find myself inadvertently clicking on apps below or other dark apps below instead of the vscode window as the edges are challenging to discern. VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Linux x64 6.15.10-200.fc42.x86_64 Modes:

title: Update assignment service change event to track queried treatments

labels.name: debt
labels.description: Code quality issues

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
RE: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/265101

In the chat extension, I keep track of all the treatments that have been queried so I can emit an event when treatments actually change. This debt item is to port that behavior over so the change event is more informative.

title: A11y: Disable forced color adjustment for Monaco editor
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

Resolves https://github.com/microsoft/monaco-editor/issues/4942 
Resolves https://github.com/microsoft/monaco-editor/issues/4945
Resolves https://github.com/microsoft/monaco-editor/issues/4985

This PR disables forced color adjustment for the Monaco editor. This change matches what we do in VS Code desktop and now the editor will rely on the custom built-in high contrast themes that we ship instead.
